snippet: The financing has prompted criticism that the military’s money could co-opt workshops where hackers gather to build, invent or take apart things in their spare time.
abstract: Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency is initiating a $10 million program at a number of American high schools to create 'hackerspaces', clubs where hackers gather to build and invent in their spare time; computer professionals have criticized the program, saying the introduction of government bureaucracy threatens to co-opt or even cut off ingenuity in the hacker community.
lead_paragraph: The financing has prompted criticism that the military’s money could co-opt workshops where hackers gather to build, invent or take apart things in their spare time.

headline.seo: Worries Over Defense Dept. Money for ‘Hackerspaces’
headline.main: Worries Over Defense Department Money for ‘Hackerspaces’
headline.print_headline: Paying Hackers, Military Forms Uneasy Alliance
